title: Many Sense Politics in Gay Rights Veto
description: In vetoing a bill intended to protect homosexuals against job discrimination, Gov. Pete Wilson said Sunday that he was trying to protect California businesses from added costs, rather than playing electoral politics.

title: What's the Use Of 'First Use'?
description: Despite the well-deserved praise for President Bush's initiative to reduce nuclear arms, two sentences in his address indicate that the U.S. still clings to a mistaken belief that has distorted its defense policy throughout the nuclear age.

title: By Design; Leader of the Pack
description: It's quite possible that you have never thought of yourself as a black-leather type. This season, though, you might.

title: A.T.&T. Links Breakdown to a Routine Oversight
description: In a report to the Federal Government yesterday on the latest accident to disrupt its long-distance service, A.T.& T. for the first time attributed the Sept. 17 incident largely to a supervisor's choosing not to dispatch a technician for a routine inspection.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: E.M.S. Crew Blamed in Childbirth Case
description: The union representing a Harlem Hospital doctor who refused admission to a woman in labor last week, citing an overcrowded obstetrics unit, charged yesterday that the ambulance crew deliberately cut the patient's amniotic fluid sac to induce labor at the hospital, where the baby was born on a stretcher.

title: Potomac Electric Power reports earnings for 12mos Aug 31
Commtron Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Redskins' Sanders Back In Step
description: The season before Ricky Sanders arrived in Washington in 1986 to become a big-play receiver for the Redskins, he had caught 101 passes (11 for touchdowns) from Jim Kelly with the Houston Gamblers of the now-defunct United States Football League. In 1988, he made an indelible mark in Super Bowl XXII, snaring an 80-yard touchdown pass from Doug Williams and gaining 193 receiving yards in that remarkable 42-10 Redskins victory over the Denver Broncos.

title: Miles Ahead
description: Unless someone soon emerges from nowhere, the trumpeter Miles Davis will be remembered as the most influential jazz artist of the second half of the 20th century. Mr. Davis remained iconoclastic through four decades as instrumentalist, composer and band leader. He felt compelled to change (a "curse," he called it) and when he did, the whole of jazz often changed with him.

title: Corrections
description: A dance review on Monday about the Pina Bausch Tanztheater Wuppertal misstated some performance dates at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. "Palermo, Palermo" will be performed through Saturday; "Bandoneon" will be presented on Oct. 8, 9, 11, 12 and 13.

title: On My Mind; The Peace Dividends
description: How swiftly and richly it has come -- the first great dividend of the disintegration of the centralized Soviet state.

title: Corrections
description: A report yesterday about the marriage of Risa Sonenshine to Matthew Crandall referred incorrectly to the bridegroom's father, H. B. Crandall. He is alive, in New York, where he heads Crandall Associates, an executive recruiting firm.

title: Key Rates
Classical Music in Review
description: Young People's Concert New York Philharmonic Avery Fisher Hall

title: Blackstone Unit to Buy Days Inns
description: A Blackstone Group subsidiary that owns the Ramada and Howard Johnson hotel chains agreed yesterday to pay $250 million for Days Inns of America Inc., the 1,214-unit franchise system burdened by some $750 million in debt.

title: Karl-Heinz Kopcke, 68, A German TV Anchor
description: Karl-Heinz Kopcke, who brought the main evening television news into the living rooms of millions of Germans for more than 28 years, died on Saturday. He was 68 years old.

title: AKIHITO VISITING ASIAN NEIGHBORS
description: Stirring curiosity abroad and anxiousness at home, Emperor Akihito has been making an extensive tour of Southeast Asia this week, marking the first visit by a Japanese ruler to a region once subjugated in the Emperor's name but now eager for Japanese aid and investment.

title: Bowl America Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Officials Saw Early Signs Of Brutalization of Girl, 8
description: Fifteen months before the police found Tiesha Carter scarred, beaten, burned and locked in a closet, teachers at Public School 229 in the Bronx told a child-abuse hot line there was evidence that she was being mistreated, an education official said yesterday.

title: Hy & Zel's reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net incomeThe company said the losses in the latest quarter and 6 months are due to the cost of closing and subletting its store in London, Ont. It said it incurred a total cost of $ 1,003,180 to complete this transaction, through tenant inducements and the write-off of leasehold improvements.

title: Din Echoing From Scripted 'Bonfire' Riot
description: A scene depicting blacks rioting in a courthouse never made it to the final version of the movie "The Bonfire of the Vanities." And the movie, long since closed in the theaters, is already available on videocassette, but the controversy involving the scene remains.

title: Nebraska Senator Enters the 1992 Race
description: To the strains of Bruce Springsteen's "Born to Run," Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska entered the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination today and asserted that a short-sighted and cynical Federal Government was robbing young Americans of their birthright of good jobs, good educations and national greatness.

title: Exxon to Pay Higher Criminal Fines In New Pact to Settle Valdez Claims
description: Five months after their first agreement collapsed, the United States, Alaska and the Exxon Corporation today announced a second, almost identical agreement to settle civil and criminal cases arising from the 1989 Exxon Valdez oil spill.

title: Parking Rules
description: Alternate-side parking rules will be suspended today for the Jewish holiday of Simhath Torah.

title: Golden Enterprises Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Revenues represented total revenues.

title: Angles Beyond Books
description: MOST adults quickly forget their high-school geometry, and good riddance. But we use a kind of intuitive geometry all the time, even when estimating the angle required to get a paper ball to the wastebasket.

title: Suit Against Piniella Is on the Move
description: A Federal judge in Philadelphia has transferred to New York a lawsuit instituted by an umpire against Cincinnati Reds Manager LOU PINIELLA. The judge also ruled that the umpires union cannot participate in the case.

title: Hewson A. Ryan, 69, Professor and Envoy
description: Hewson A. Ryan, the Edward R. Murrow Professor of Public Diplomacy emeritus at the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Tufts University, died Saturday at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston. He was 69 years old.

title: Richard Barrie Fragrances Inc. reports earnings for Year to June 30
Club Med Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company said the latest quarter included a $ 165,000 loss from foreign currency exchange. The year-ago quarter included foreign currency gains of $ 2,079,000.

title: Bank Reform Blunder
description: The banking reform bill now working its way through Congress has a provision that would require Federal regulators to take control of a bank automatically when its capital falls below 2 percent of its assets. The reason: fast action could keep the problems, generally thought to come from bad management, from worsening.

title: In Search of Greener Showrooms
description: Tony Salcido, who sells Toyotas in Puente Hills, Calif., is the kind of salesman who makes car companies both smile and cringe.

title: New Debate Over Humankind's Ancestress
description: SHE may no longer be called Eve, and her most imaginative and outspoken proponent may have died two months ago, but the provocative notion that our genes hold evidence of a mother of us all is growing ever more powerful.

title: For U.S. Arms Complex, Much Work, Then Less
description: President Bush's call for the destruction of thousands of nuclear arms will probably keep the nation's huge weapons complex busy in the short term but will eventually speed its contraction, Federal and private experts say.

title: Hawks Sign Augmon and Drop Moncrief
description: The Atlanta Hawks have signed STACEY AUGMON of Nevada-Las Vegas, the ninth player selected in the National Basketball Association draft, after renouncing the rights to veteran SIDNEY MONCRIEF in order to free money for the rookie's contract.

title: Everex Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included pretax charges from write-downs of the company's inventories and certain other assets of $ 24,815,000 in the quarter and $ 36,237,000 in the year.c-Net incomeThe company said that after taking into account the nearly $ 25 million fourth quarter pretax charge, the balance of the fourth quarter loss is primarily attributable to continued pressure on gross margins and increased selling expenses.

title: Review/Film Festival; What Was New (and Rude) in 1962
description: Unlike a lot of avant-garde films, which age faster than fondled gardenias, Jack Smith's "Flaming Creatures" remains as vigorously funny and innocent today as it was 29 years ago, when it outraged the censors and the police on two continents.

title: The Mets' Manager for 1992? Try Cubbage, Says Cubbage
description: "I never had that much talent as a player," said Mike Cubbage, who was named interim manager of the Mets on Sunday. "But I've got good instincts for the game."

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Smoltz, a Second-Half Rose, Throws a Beauty
description: In July, John Smoltz felt he was only two games away from losing his spot in Atlanta's starting pitching rotation. Now he and the Braves are only five games away from possibly gaining a spot in the National League pennant playoff.

title: Q&A
description: Venomous Spiders

title: Isco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Topics of The Times; Rockers of the World
description: Just as President Bush was announcing reductions in nuclear weaponry last weekend, casting new light on 40 years of past rivalry, young people in Moscow joined in two events that cast new light on the future.

title: Soviets Reject Fast Reply on Arms Saying Talks Must Be Held First
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev indicated today that the Soviet Union would not rush to respond to President Bush's initiative in reducing nuclear weapons, and a senior Foreign Ministry official said it was important to begin discussions with Washington on the issue first.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PETER MAX is hardly resting on his laurels as a central figure of the 1960's Pop Art scene. On Sunday, he flew from Chicago, where he opened a show, to New York to complete work for a show that opens Oct. 16 at the Hanson Gallery in SoHo. Yesterday, he was off to Los Angeles to join TED TURNER and JANE FONDA at a dinner, and this morning he was to go to San Francisco.

title: Grace Zaring Stone, a Novelist Under Two Names, Dies at 100
description: Grace Zaring Stone, a novelist who also wrote under the pen name Ethel Vance, died on Sunday at the Mary Elizabeth Nursing Center in Mystic, Conn. She was 100 years old and had lived in Stonington, Conn.

title: National Heritage Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included $ 7.9 million non-recurring provision for a variety of estimated losses related to the bankruptcy of Southmark Corp. and the further unwinding of National Heritage's relationship with Southmark related entities.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Metropolitan Transportation Authority, New York, said its five-year, multibillion-dollar capital improvement plan would include about $640 million in new bond financing by the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority.

title: GTE Studies Spinoff or Sale of Unit
description: The GTE Corporation said yesterday that it might sell its $2.3 billion electrical products group, including Sylvania light bulbs, which would allow it to concentrate more on its already huge telecommunications business.

title: CCA Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Dublin Journal; Will Haughey Get the Heave? It's an Irish Riddle
description: The ancient Celts, fierce in battle though they were, had a nagging fear that if they angered the gods, the sky would fall on their heads. Their descendants, especially Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey, probably know the feeling.

title: Turner Deal Is Held Near
description: The Turner Broadcasting System is close to making final its acquisition of Hanna-Barbera Productions for about $320 million, according to several executives familiar with the negotiations. An executive at the Great American Communications Company, which owns Hanna-Barbera, declined to comment yesterday.

title: A Convenient Box
description: THE Iomega Corporation has increased the capacity and decreased the price of its Bernoulli Box, which is good news even for people who are thinking, "What's a Bernoulli box?"

title: Naming of 7 Moons
description: Six moons of Neptune that were discovered by the Voyager 2 spacecraft in 1989 have been named after water nymphs and relatives and lovers of the mythological Greek sea god Poseidon.

title: Cooper's Deputy Chairmen
description: Eugene M. Freedman, the new chairman of the accounting firm Coopers & Lybrand, yesterday announced the names of the deputy chairmen who would begin serving when he took over the top spot today.

title: TALE OF REVENGE STIRS AIDS FUROR
description: In a chilling radio interview on Sept. 4, a woman who said she had AIDS told how she was trying to spread the virus out of revenge on the man who had infected her.

title: Review/Television; The Powers of Hair, and Its Loss
description: "Nova" begins a new season tonight at 8 on Channels 13 and 49 with "Sex, Lies and Toupee Tape," a pateful of information about how hair grows and why it stops growing and what losers can do about it. The snappy spirit -- Alan Rachins of "L.A. Law" narrates with the help of billiard balls -- seems appropriate, although for men who invest substantial sums in drugs, transplants and toupees, baldness is evidently no laughing matter. (Young and middle-aged women do not seem to be as prone to fallout.)

title: Business and Health; Companies Make H.M.O. Deals
description: TURNING the H.M.O. concept on its head, a handful of companies have pursuaded health- maintenance organizations to charge on a fee-for-service basis, instead of taking the usual prepaid fee that covers employees even if they do not need medical attention.

title: Miscellany
description: * An investor group led by Ruth Ratny, publisher of Screen, a trade magazine in Chicago, announced yesterday that it had purchased rights to the Clio Awards from Bill Evans of Clio Awards Enterprises, New York. Terms were not disclosed, nor were the identities of the other group members.

title: BUSH'S ARMS PLAN: Battle Cry In Congress; Lawmakers Brace For Fight on Arms
description: In his speech to the nation on Friday night, outlining major reductions in American nuclear armaments, President Bush warned against "unwise or unwarranted cuts in the defense budget" and said he was "counting on Congressional support" for his plans for the future.

title: Democrats Seek More U.S. Campaign Grants
description: Congressional Democrats have moved to put their party's Presidential hopefuls in a better position to collect Federal money for their primary campaigns than the Treasury Department wanted.

title: Judge Denounces 'Lawless' Beating by Police at Rally
description: A Criminal Court judge in Manhattan declared in a decision yesterday that the police beat an Act Up demonstrator without provocation in February and then did not tell the truth about the incident.

title: Sports of The Times; The Rookie Coach And The Ghost
description: AT Ray Handley's news conference yesterday afternoon, someone asked him a question -- virtually every question had something to do with how come the defending Super Bowl champs are in amongst the chumps in the standings -- and on this question the rookie Giant coach remained silent.

title: Maris's Big Moment: Deliveries Differed
description: Red Barber was never one for broadcasting with naked emotion, so 30 years ago today, on a sunny fall day when Roger Maris hit his 61st home run off Tracy Stallard of the Red Sox, Barber did not let the moment move him.

title: Cree Chief Asks New York To Drop Hydroelectric Plan
description: A Cree Indian chief from Quebec's sub-Arctic came to New York City yesterday to urge the state to cancel huge contracts for hydroelectricity that would be generated on his native land, but state officials strongly suggested that they favored moving ahead with the purchase.

title: Lotus Executive Moves To Wang Laboratories
description: Donald P. Casey has been appointed executive vice president and chief development officer of Wang Laboratories Inc. He comes to Wang from the Lotus Development Corporation, where he was in charge of development and product marketing for the company's spreadsheet products.

description: THE discovery of a 4,000-year-old mummified man in a glacier in Austria late last month is the most complete Bronze Age find in Europe and may also provide new insight into ancient weather conditions, scientists say.

description: New York City, which usually sells securities through competitive bidding, expects to sell about $1.25 billion worth of revenue anticipation notes next week on a negotiated basis. The notes, which will be due in June 1992, will be handled through an underwriting group led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JOHN FAIRCHILD'S idea of a party: "Six people is fine, eight I can cope with, but more than that, I don't know," he said yesterday. About 200 people were invited last night to celebrate the arrival of Suzy at Women's Wear Daily on Oct. 9. But how do you pare the list of AILEEN MEHLE'S (that's Suzy's real name) nearest and dearest? The guest list had everyone from BROOKE ASTOR to WALTER ANNENBERG, CALVIN KLEINto LAURANCE S. ROCKEFELLER.

title: A Further Reduction For Unisys
description: The Unisys Corporation said yesterday that it planned to sell its military electronics business through a stock offering that could raise up to $800 million for the debt-burdened computer company. Unisys was apparently unable to find a corporate buyer for the business, which was on the block for more than a year.

title: Review/Dance; Images of Horror and Lust In Montreal
description: Whatever Pina Bausch hath wrought, it hath not been a major influence in the United States, where experimental dance has been virtually unaffected by her brand of dance theater. But Miss Bausch's penchant for subordinating conventional dance movement to dramatic imagery, often confessional, is still shared by many European and French Canadian choreographers.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Svensson Is Upset Ronald Agenor of Haiti upset fourth-seeded Jonas Svensson of Sweden by 6-4, 7-6 yesterday in the first round of the Toulouse Open. In other matches in the French event, Spain's Tomas Carbonell defeated Guillaume Raoux of France, 6-7, 6-4, 6-3, and Sweden's Christian Bergstrom beat Jean-Philippe Fleurian of France, 6-7, 6-1, 6-1. (AP) HORSE RACING Island Edition Wins Island Edition took over in the stretch to win by a half length yesterday in the $47,000 Believe It purse at Belmont. Owned by Hazel P. Marsh, Island Edition carried 115 pounds, including Mike Smith, in the race for horses 3-year-olds and up. Island Edition covered the mile in 1:35 to earn $28,200 (AP)

description: Roger J. Robach, the deputy majority leader of the New York State Assembly, died on Sunday in Strong Memorial Hospital in Rochester. He was 57 years old and lived in Rochester.

title: Weekend Staple: Versatile Jacket

It ends in April and May, with the arrival of clothes to wear through August and beyond. While these clothes include daytime styles that can be worn comfortably in boardrooms and offices and festive dresses to wear to parties, the emphasis is on casual clothes for weekends and vacations.

title: Topics of The Times; Fair Honoraria Fix
description: The 1989 Ethics Reform Act, which barred House members and other high Government officials from accepting outside fees for writing articles or giving speeches, was a major advance for clean government. But the act may have gone too far when it extended the honoraria ban to low- and middle-level workers whose duties make them unlikely targets for disguised payoffs. Sensible legislation now moving through Congress would strike a fairer balance.

description: Two years ago, President Bush and the nation's 50 governors, at a celebrated education summit conference, agreed to six national education goals to be achieved by the year 2000. It took them two years to decide how to measure progress toward the goals, but today they issued their first "report card" on that progress.

title: Packers Trade Harris to 49ers
description: TIM HARRIS was traded yesterday from Green Bay to the San Francisco 49ers, who gave the Packers two high draft picks for the holdout linebacker.

description: Jeff Hostetler and Bart Oates are frustrated. Mark Ingram is puzzled. Ray Handley is more disappointed than upset. And Lawrence Taylor is angry, angry enough to call a players meeting, probably on Wednesday, to get his fellow Giants to start playing well enough to win again.

title: Lights, Cameras and a Sudden Surge in Action

Horns honked, cabbies rubbernecked, pedestrians gawked and the New York-born director Paul Mazursky yelled "Action!" The New York-born actor Danny Aiello began speaking on cue in a movie about New York.

description: In the latest of a series of political concessions, President Najibullah called today for provincial and local elections with the participation of all political groups, including the rebel mujahedeen. These local elections, the President said, would be a prelude to national elections envisaged for next year.

description: The Dinkins administration has warned labor leaders that it is considering paring proposed property-tax increases, a decision that would deprive them of an important source of money for wage increases.

description: Madge the manicurist, the advertising character who has touted Palmolive dishwashing liquid for more than two decades, may no longer be surprising customers with her trademark line, "You're soaking in it."

description: ERIC LINDROS may be allowed to play in the National Hockey League this year even if he misses tomorrow's deadline to sign with an N.H.L. team, the head of the Canadian Hockey League said yesterday.

description: FOR bondholders around the world, the summer of 1991 was a joyous time. With interest rates generally falling, their profits soared.

description: American elementary and secondary school pupils have made some educational progress in recent years, but they are only now reaching the achievement levels of students in 1970, according to a major Federal report issued today, which added that students are unprepared for the complex and demanding world of the 21st century.
